 A bucket is similar to a folder or directory in a filesystem, where each bucket can hold an arbitrary number of objects.

links.title: Bucket Versioning
links.body: MinIO supports keeping multiple “versions” of an object in a single bucket. MinIO versioning protects from unintended overwrites and deletions while providing support for “undoing” a write operation.

links.title: How is failed replication handled?
links.body: MinIO queues failed replication operations and retries those operations until replication succeeds.

links.title: What are Replication Workers?
links.body: MinIO uses a replication queuing system with multiple concurrent replication workers operating on that queue.

links.title: Where can I see current Heal status?
links.body: Check under Monitoring/Drives on the left hand  menu to see Drive and Bucket Healing status

links.title: How is Erasure Coding used to Protect Data?
links.body: MinIO erasure coding is a data redundancy and  availability feature that allows MinIO deployments to  automatically reconstruct objects on-the-fly despite  the loss of multiple drives or nodes in the cluster.

links.title: Recover After Hardware failure
links.body: Depending on the deployment topology and  selected erasure code parity, MinIO can tolerate loss  of up to half the drives or nodes in the deployment  while maintaining read access to objects.

links.title: Site Failure Recovery
links.body: MinIO can make the loss of an entire site, while  significant, a relatively minor incident. Site recovery depends on the replication option you use for the site.

links.title: Node Failure Recovery
links.body: If a MinIO node suffers complete hardware failure, the node begins healing operations once it rejoins the  deployment.

links.title: What is MinIO Healing?
links.body: Healing is MinIO’s ability to restore data after some event causes data loss. Data loss can come from bit rot, drive loss, or node loss.

links.title: Understand MinIO Healing Using mc
links.body: The mc admin heal command scans for objects that are damaged or corrupted and heals those objects.

links.title: What is Bit Rot?
links.body: Bit rot is data corruption that occurs without the user’s knowledge. MinIO combats bit rot with hashing and erasure coding.

links.title: Overview of MinIO Erasure Coding
links.body: Through this MinIO video you will learn about MinIO erasure coding, including erasure sets, erasure parity, and stripe size. You will also learn about how the Reed-Solomon algorithm can be optimized for storage efficiency (yielding cost savings) or data lost protection (number of servers and drives that can fail). The video also walks through the MinIO Erasure Code calculator, considerations for cluster design and the command line syntax needed to establish an erasure code deployment.

links.title: What is the Scanner?
links.body: One of several low-priority processes MinIO runs to check lifecycle management rules, bucket or site replication status, as well as object bit rot and healing

links.title: Lifecycle Management Object Scanner Considerations
links.body: MinIO uses a scanner process to check objects against all configured lifecycle management rules. High IO workloads or limited system resources may delay application of lifecycle management rules

links.title: Identity and Access Management
links.body: MinIO uses Policy-Based Access Control (PBAC) to define the authorized actions and resources to which an authenticated user has access.

links.title: User Management
links.body: Each user can have one or more assigned policies that explicitly list the actions and resources to which that user has access. Users can also inherit policies from the groups in which they have membership.

links.title: Group Management
links.body: A group is a collection of users. Each group can have one or more assigned policies that explicitly list the actions and resources to which group members are allowed or denied access.

links.title: Identity and Access Management
links.body: MinIO uses Policy-Based Access Control (PBAC) to define the authorized actions and resources to which an authenticated user has access.

links.title: Group Management
links.body: A group is a collection of users. Each group can have one or more assigned policies that explicitly list the actions and resources to which group members are allowed or denied access.

links.title: User Management
links.body: Each user can have one or more assigned policies that explicitly list the actions and resources to which that user has access. Users can also inherit policies from the groups in which they have membership.

docs.header: Healing is MinIO’s ability to restore data after some event causes data loss. Data loss can come from bit rot, drive loss, or node loss.

links.title: Drive Healing
links.body: The Drives section displays the healing status for a bucket.

links.title: Erasure Coding
links.body: MinIO Erasure Coding is a data redundancy and availability feature that allows MinIO deployments to automatically reconstruct objects on-the-fly despite the loss of multiple drives or nodes in the cluster.

links.title: Site Healing
links.body: Any MinIO deployment in the site replication configuration can resynchronize damaged replica-eligible data from the peer with the most updated (“latest”) version of that data.

links.title: Healing
links.body: MinIO Automatically Heals Corrupt or Missing Data On-the-fly

links.title: Site Replication Overview
links.body: In this video, we will provide an overview of site-wide replication.

links.title: Overview of MinIO Erasure Coding
links.body: Through this MinIO video you will learn about MinIO erasure coding, including erasure sets, erasure parity, and stripe size. You will also learn about how the Reed-Solomon algorithm can be optimized for storage efficiency (yielding cost savings) or data lost protection (number of servers and drives that can fail). The video also walks through the MinIO Erasure Code calculator, considerations for cluster design and the command line syntax needed to establish an erasure code deployment.

links.title: Replication Best Practices

links.title: Faster Multi-Site Replication and Resync

links.title: Erasure Coding 101
links.body: Learn how erasure coding is implemented in MinIO, and how it satisfies enterprise requirements for data protection.

links.body: Learn how to set up Active-Active site replication across 3 sites for a high availability email provider.

links.title: Multi-Site Active-Active Replication
links.body: Active-Active replication enables multi-primary topologies, fast hot-hot failover, and multi-geo resiliency.

links.title: What is SUBNET?
links.body: The MinIO Subscription Network (SUBNET for short) is a simple, yet powerful software stack that ensures commercial customers are getting the very best out of their MinIO instances.

links.title: SUBNET Healthcheck
links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.title: Direct-to-Engineer Engagement
links.body: When things get big, cross clouds or involve mission-critical workloads, even the most sophisticated enterprises want someone on the other end of the line.

links.title: The Beauty of the Panic Button
links.body: The Panic Button is remarkable in its simplicity and its power. When pressed it summons every engineer to your SUBNET issue. Everyone. On every continent. Instantaneously. It is, effectively, an instantaneous SLA.

links.title: Supportability as Software with MinIO SUBNET
links.body: In the same way that DevOps and Cloud Native require a rethinking of old paradigms of development, MinIO’s approach to supportability is driving new thinking on support.

links.title: Why our Customers Buy
links.body: We recently asked our customer base to participate in a flash survey to tell us what motivated them to buy and why. Here is what they told us.

links.title: What is SUBNET?
links.body: The MinIO Subscription Network (SUBNET for short) is a simple, yet powerful software stack that ensures commercial customers are getting the very best out of their MinIO instances.

links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.title: The Beauty of the Panic Button
links.body: The Panic Button is remarkable in its simplicity and its power. When pressed it summons every engineer to your SUBNET issue. Everyone. On every continent. Instantaneously. It is, effectively, an instantaneous SLA.

links.title: Supportability as Software with MinIO SUBNET
links.body: In the same way that DevOps and Cloud Native require a rethinking of old paradigms of development, MinIO’s approach to supportability is driving new thinking on support.

links.title: Object Locking
links.body: MinIO Object Locking (“Object Retention”) enforces Write-Once Read-Many (WORM) immutability to protect versioned objects from deletion.

links.title: Encryption
links.body: MinIO Server-Side Encryption (SSE) protects objects as part of write operations, allowing clients to take advantage of server processing power to secure objects at the storage layer (encryption-at-rest).

links.title: Bucket Versioning
links.body: MinIO versioning protects from unintended overwrites and deletions while providing support for “undoing” a write operation.

links.body: MinIO uses Policy-Based Access Control (PBAC) to define the authorized actions and resources to which an authenticated user has access.

links.title: User Management
links.body: Each user can have one or more assigned policies that explicitly list the actions and resources to which that user has access. Users can also inherit policies from the groups in which they have membership.

links.title: What is SUBNET?
links.body: The MinIO Subscription Network (SUBNET for short) is a simple, yet powerful software stack that ensures commercial customers are getting the very best out of their MinIO instances.

links.title: SUBNET Callhome Diagnostics
links.body: Imagine tracking your system's health daily, highlighting the slightest problems, so you can seek help before minor issues become major concerns.

links.title: SUBNET Healthcheck
links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.body: Use the Event framework to see what's going on in the system using Bucket, Object, Replication and ILM events.

links.title: Managing Objects with Tagging and Policies
links.body: Learn how to use tags to enable fine-grained object access, event notifications and lifecycle management.

links.body: Imagine a system that tracks your health daily, highlighting even the slightest problems, so that you can seek help before minor issues become major concerns. With MinIO’s new call-home diagnostics, you can have just that.

links.title: SUBNET Healthcheck
links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.title: Active Directory / LDAP Access Management
links.body: For identities managed by the external AD/LDAP provider, MinIO uses the user’s Distinguished Name and attempts to map it against an existing policy.

links.title: IDP Docs
links.body: MinIO supports multiple external identity managers through OpenID Connect-Compatible Active Directory / LDAP

links.title: LDAP Configuration
links.body: MinIO supports configuring a single Active Directory / LDAP Connect for external management of user identities.
